#Text=Wernigerode

#Text=Described by the German heath poet , Hermann Löns , as the " brightly coloured town by the Harz " , Wernigerode is an attractive destination on the Holtemme river , nestling against the northern foothills of said mountain range .

column1: #Text=Understand

#Text=Wernigeorde 's charm — derived from its impressive medieval-era Old Town with its fascinating fairy-tale castle and rows of centuries-old timber-framed houses — have led to it becoming a popular waystop on two major tourist routes : the German Timber-Framed Road and the Orange Route , a German-Dutch holiday road .
#Text=The town is also a good base for exploring the northern Harz on foot or by mountain bike .
#Text=Tourist Information , Marktplatz 10 , ☏ +4939435537835 .
#Text=History
#Text=Wernigerode is first recorded in 1121 when it was the seat of the medieval County of Wernigerode , a status it held until 1429 .
#Text=It was during that time , in 1229 , that it was granted town rights .
#Text=Wernigerode 's heyday came during the 14th and 15th centuries as it grew wealthy through trading in cloth , beer and brandy .
#Text=However , it suffered from plague epidemics in the 16th century as well as the ravages of the Thirty Years ' War and fell into decline .
#Text=From 1645 to 1807 , Wernigerode was the seat of the County of Stolberg-Wernigerode .
#Text=At the end of the 18th century , the town 's economy picked up again , this time based on tanning and the manufacture of cloth and linen .
#Text=In 1815 it was absorbed into the Prussian Province of Saxony .
#Text=During the Industrial Revolution , new metal and wood industries settling here .
#Text=The railways arrived in 1872 , the same year that the Harz 's best known brewery , the Hasseröder Brauerei , was founded .
#Text=After the Second World War , Wernigerode fell on the East German side of the Inner German Border in the newly-created state Saxony-Anhalt .
#Text=Wernigerode became part of the restored state of Saxony-Anhalt in 1990 after German reunification and did not take long to restore the beauty of its timber-framed town houses .
#Text=Wernigerode has a population of about 35,000 .
#Text=By car
#Text=Wernigerode has two junctions ( Wernigerode-Nord and Wernigerode-Zentrum ) on the B 6 , a motorway-like dual carriageway that runs along the northern edge of the Harz from west to east .
#Text=The B 6 branches off the A 7 motorway near Goslar and the A 395 motorway from Brunswick to Vienenburg .
#Text=By train
#Text=is on the Heudeber-Danstedt –
#Text=Vienenburg line with two-hourly services that run between Hanover and Halle using the Harzexpress .
#Text=Wernigerode is also the main depot and terminus on the Harz Narrow Gauge Railways .
#Text=Trains , including steam-hauled services , than run to various destinations in the Harz , including its highest mountain , the Brocken .
#Text=Tip : The HarzTourCard enables you to travel by bus , train and narrow gauge train ( except trains to the summit of Brocken ) as much as you like within three days .
#Text=It costs € 18 for a single card , € 34.50 for a family .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Wernigerode is about 1 hr 15 min by car from Hanover airport and about 1½ hours from Leipzig airport .
#Text=On foot

#Text=The vast majority of Wernigerode 's important tourist sites are contained within the compact area of the old town , whose narrow cobbled streets are n't particularly amenable to motorized transportation .
#Text=Walking is probably the most sensible way to get around .
#Text=By car
#Text=If you 're staying in a further-flung area , your best bet is to leave your car at one of the several car parks or roadside parking meter bays near the centre .
#Text=By bus

#Text=The local public transport organization Harzer Verkehrsbetriebe ( HVB ) operates a municipal bus network throughout the city , consisting of four lines that converge on the , located at Ringstraße 31 in the centre of town .
#Text=Regular buses run seven days a week , from roughly 06:00 until 19:00 on weekdays and 09:00 until 17:30 on Saturdays , Sundays and legal holidays .
#Text=From roughly 19:00 until 00:00 , there 's also more limited service courtesy of a night bus ( Abendlinie ) .
#Text=HVB 's website includes a system map and schedules for each route .
#Text=See
#Text=Wernigerode has a wealth of historic sights and curiosities .
#Text=Without a shadow of doubt , though , its top sights are its preserved medieval castle overlooking the town and its splendid town hall .

#Text=But wandering around its ancient , sometimes still cobbled streets , the tourist will come across rows of colourful timber-framed houses and oddities like the Leaning House and the tiny " Smallest House " in Wernigerode , as well as museums that reflect the town 's history and culture .
#Text=Old fortifications
#Text=Wernigerode Castle ( Schloss Wernigerode ) , Am Schloss 1 ( follow the signs from the town centre ) .
#Text=A walk around this striking medieval castle is well worth the effort of the climb from the town centre .
#Text=There are numerous paths through the woods and grounds of the castle .
#Text=A climb onto the Agnesberg hill behind it is rewarded with a view over the castle , the town , and the edge of the Harz mountains that many visitors simply miss .

#Text=The more adventurous can make their way through the woods into the valley of Christianental , where there is a forest inn serving traditional German fare and a small wildlife park with deer , wild boar and birds of prey .
#Text=The castle is now a museum which is open to the public - see " Museums " section below .
#Text=Emperor Tower ( Kaiserturm ) .
#Text=24 hours a day .

#Text=This stone observation tower is not part of the town 's old fortifications , though it certainly looks of a piece with the remaining medieval-era towers : named and dedicated in honor of Kaiser Wilhelm II , the Kaiserturm has stood since 1902 at the 478-m summit of the Armeleuteberg hill a short distance south of the town centre .
#Text=From its top , you can enjoy breathtaking views of the castle and old town of Wernigerode and out to the high summits of the North Harz .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Half Tower ( Halbschalenturm ) , north side of Burgberg between Nöschenröder Straße and Lindenallee .

#Text=In the middle of a small park near the castle is another remnant of Wernigerode 's medieval city wall : the semicircular shell of one of the old watchtowers ( the side facing away from the castle is open ) that was the object of a partial restoration in the 19th century at the request of Count Otto zu Stolberg-Wernigerode , and now is protected from the elements by a new slate roof .
#Text=Western Gate Tower ( Westerntorturm ) , Westernstraße at Ringstraße .
#Text=This imposing tower , 38 m high , is first recorded in 1356 and acted as a toll gate .
#Text=It was built in Early Gothic style and formed part of Wernigerode 's city wall .
